title: Alfredsson helping Lazar with shot | Hockey | Sports | Toronto Sun
text:
Like he was during his storied playing career with the Senators, it appears Daniel Alfredsson will be Mr. Everything in his new off-ice role as well.
As the formal part of morning skate was wrapping up at the Canadian Tire Centre Saturday, the 42-year-old Alfredsson, who looks like he could play, skated onto the ice in a track suit and spent more than 30 minutes working with a group of forwards on shooting the puck.
Alfredsson went out specifically to work with second-year winger Curtis Lazar but it didn't take long for a crowd to gather round.
"It's awesome," said Lazar. "He's going to lend a hand in every way, shape and form that he can. He definitely has a big influence. I know, for myself, staying on the ice 10 or 15 minutes after practice working on a couple of skills here and there is really going to help my game.
"Just having him around the room, in general, brings the moral up."
The Senators have told Lazar they want him to use his shot more to score more goals this season and Alfredsson was providing tips on shot placement with a little help from goalie Craig Anderson.
"He was probably the most excited guy to be on the ice today," Lazar said. "I talked to him (Friday) and I know he wanted to get out there specifically with me to work on some shooting stuff and like that. It's one thing for him to say but to see him out there ... all of us have big respect for a guy like him and for him to come out here it's definitely special.
"What can't you learn? He's got so much knowledge in every area of the game. His stats speak for themselves but just the kind of person he is but for him to take time out his day to help ... Today we worked on my angles, shifting my hips a bit and working with Andy as well. Stuff like that can make me go from scoring six goals to 20 pretty fast."
Coach Dave Cameron said Alfredsson will be on the ice "as needed." It makes sense, he scored 444 goals in his 1,246-game career.
"We're still feeling our way around here," Cameron said. "We're going to use him."
Lazar said just having Alfredsson around has been great.
"He knows a thing or two about the league, how it works, the city of Ottawa and the Senators," Lazar said. "If I can have him on my side and stay in his good books then I think I'll have a pretty good career."
